Graphical abstract Three-dimensional ordered macroporous hybrid catalyst 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 was prepared by the sol–gel method using polystyrene (PS) latex sphere as the template with self-assembly method. The as-sample was remained three-dimensional ordered macroporous structure after incorporation PW11Co. Simultaneously, PW11Co was anchored on the surface of APS-3DOM TiO2 via CoN dative bonding. The absorption band of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 was broadened. The photocatalytic performance of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 was evaluated using the degradation of organic pollutants and the possible procedure and mechanism of the photodegradation was well discussed. A novel and efficient, amine-functionalized three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) titanium (Ti) catalyst modified using transition metal-monosubstituted polyoxometalate (3DOM K5[Co(H2O)PW11O39]–(EtO)3SiCH2CH2CH2NH2–TiO2 or 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2) was fabricated by self-assembly method. First, methanol bath was used to soak polystyrene spheres to obtain large size 3DOM TiO2, which was further functionalized using 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APS). Amine-functionalized 3DOM TiO2 materials impregnated with monosubstituted polyoxometalate (POM, K5[Co(H2O)PW11O39]) were prepared by coordination of cobalt (Co) present in the units of POM, with the amine groups present on the surface of 3DOM TiO2. The materials so obtained were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry, Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Scanning electron microscopy, Transmission electron microscopy, and nitrogen adsorption–desorption tests. The results showed that the primary Keggin structures of the composites remained intact, simultaneously, 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 had anatase crystalline structure, and PW11Co was successfully bonded to 3DOM TiO2 by CoN bond with APS as the coupling agent. Broadening of absorption band was observed for the product compared to the monomers, 3DOM TiO2 and PW11Co. However, the 3DOM structure was retained in the product; therefore, the accessibility of the diffusing species was significantly improved because of the permeability offered by the macroporous structure. The UV photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants revealed better activities of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 compared to PW11Co, 3DOM TiO2, and PW11Co–APS–TiO2. Moreover, 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 exhibited superior photocatalytic degradation of Rhodamine B (RB), Salicylic acid (SA), Congo red (CR), and Malachite green oxalate (MG) under microwave-assisted irradiation. Leakage of PW11Co from the hybrid photocatalyst was barely observed during the photocatalytic tests, attributed to strong coordination interactions between the Keggin units and the amine-functionalized Ti surface. The capture experimental results of photocatalysis revealed that the dominant active species were OH• and O2−•. Moreover, in this study, the procedure and possible mechanism of the UV photodegradation of organic pollutants in the aqueous system was proposed and discussed. Keywords Self-assembly Three-dimensionally ordered macroporous structure Polyoxometalate Titanium dioxide Photocatalysis 1 Introduction Recently, photocatalysis has attracted significant attention due to its promising application in decomposition of environmental pollutants [1–3]. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) has been extensively employed because it is inexpensive, non-toxic, and photo and chemically stable. Moreover, it exhibits potential applications in catalysis. However, its major limitations include low quantum yield and the limited photoresponding range (usually <380nm) [4]. Therefore, to overcome the above mentioned problems, extensive research efforts have been devoted to fabricate the catalyst with different morphology and enhanced activity. Till date, various interesting textural materials such as nanofibers, nanotubes, nanosponges, and spheres [5–7] have been synthesized for the photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants. However, three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) materials, recently prepared using colloidal crystals have captured the interest of the scientists [8]. Intrinsic interconnected pore systems of the macrostructures can efficiently improve the reaction/diffusion properties for catalysis and separation processes [9]. Therefore, TiO2 configured to 3DOM morphology can act as promising candidate for an efficient catalyst system. Over the past decade, the properties of polyoxometalates (POMs) have been a subject of significant interest due to their potential applications in structural analytical chemistry, medicine, electrochemistry, and photochemistry [10]. POMs have excellent photochemical nature in a homogeneous system, due to their unique structure; however, the main disadvantages of POMs as photocatalysts lie in their low surface area and difficulty in separation from the reaction mixtures. Therefore, recent investigations have revealed that immobilization of soluble POM onto the suitable supports is an effective method to overcome the above mentioned problems and aided in developing a novel solid catalyst with advanced characteristics and high efficiency. Moreover, POM has empty d orbitals that can be used as good electron acceptors, and the rapid recombination of the charge-pair (h+–e−) can be retarded effectively [11]. In previous studies, metal semiconductors saturated with POMs have been prepared by impregnation method; however, synthetic products incorporating POMs dissolved readily during the photocatalytic process; thus, making it extremely difficult to separate the catalyst from heterogeneous reaction systems, for reuse and recycling. Therefore, in this study, APS was selected as the coupling agent to obtain 3DOM TiO2 modified with POM through CoN bond to facilitate easy recovery of the catalyst for recycling. Moreover, polystyrene (PS) spheres were synthesized by an emulsifier-free emulsion polymerization method, using titanium tetraisopropoxide (Ti(OC4H9)4, TTIP) as the Ti source, and 3DOM TiO2 was synthesized using methanol bath and selected as the support. Subsequently, APS was employed to obtain amine-functionalized TiO2 and monosubstituted POM (PW11Co) as the inorganic precursors to prepare hybrid photocatalyst through CoN coordination bond. Moreover, incorporation of interconnected macropores in so obtained hybrid photocatalysts increased the permeability of the system, thus significantly improving the mass transport through the composite and restraining the recombination of photo-electrons and holes. Furthermore, synergistic effect was observed between 3DOM TiO2 and PW11Co, which promoted the electron transfer, and improved the photocatalytic activity. Further, the photocatalytic activities of the so obtained hybrid photocatalyst were investigated by UV light irradiation and microwave-assisted irradiation. The dominant active species during the photocatalytic process was investigated by the capture experiment and the possible procedure and mechanism were discussed in this study. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials TTIP was purchased from New Jersey. APS (analytical grade) was purchased from J & K Chemical Inc., Beijing, China. The following reagents and samples were of analytical grade and were used without further purification: Styrene, Degussa P25, potassium persulfate (K2S2O8), silver nitrate (AgNO3), toluene, nitric acid, Rhodamine B (RB), Salicylic acid (SA), Congo red (CR), and Malachite green oxalate (MG), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), and manganese sulfate hexahydrate (MnSO4·6H2O). The above mentioned reagents were purchased from Beijing Chemical Inc., China. K5[Co(H2O)PW11O39](PW11Co) was prepared by the literature methods [12]. Deionized and doubly distilled water was used in all the experiments. Molecular structures of RB, SA, CR and MG are shown in Fig. 1 . 2.2 Catalysts preparation Scheme 1 shows the schematic representation of the fabrication of 3DOM Ti support, and PS spheres were synthesized by an emulsifier-free emulsion polymerization method [13] . The ordered PS colloidal crystal templates obtained by centrifugation were soaked into an absolute methanol bath for half an hour. Subsequently, the PS templates were taken out from the methanol bath and immersed in TTIP. After vacuum impregnation for ca. 10h, the mixture was annealed at 500°C for 7h to remove the PS crystal templates, resulting in the formation of 3DOM TiO2. 3DOM APS–TiO2 support was prepared as follows: Dried 3DOM TiO2 support (1.0g) was dispersed in toluene (50mL) followed by the addition of APS (1.5mL). This mixture was stirred vigorously at room temperature for 12h while reflux was used. Finally, the product 3DOM APS–TiO2 was recovered by centrifugation. Preparation of the composite 3DOM PW11M–APS–TiO2 ((MCo, Ni, Mn) is illustrated in Scheme 2 and it was fabricated as follows: 3DOM APS–TiO2 support (0.50g) was dispersed in an aqueous PW11Co solution (0.25g in 50mL water). The acidity of the mixture was controlled at pH 6 and 7. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature, centrifuged, and dried to obtain the hybrid catalysts. PW11Co was selected to anchor onto the amine-functionalized 3DOM TiO2 because of the following two reasons: first, TTIP was able to hydrolyze under acidic condition generating hydroxyl groups of titania (TiOH) on the surface of Ti; thus, demonstrating chemical reactivity. Second, the titania support was modified by the propylamine groups through the hydroxyl groups present on the surface of titania, and then PW11Co was chemically anchored to the amine-modified titania surface through CoN dative bonding. The starting PW11Co cluster exhibited weak coordinate interaction between the Co atom and aqua ligand; therefore, this coordinate site could be displaced by some ligands such as amido group leading to the formation of a new coordinate bond (CoN). 2.3 Characterization Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was recorded on American Nicolet Infrared spectrometer. KBr is used for tabletted, recording range is 4000–400cm−1, and resolution is 4cm−1. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a German Bruker-AXS (D8) X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Tube voltage is 40kV, Anti-scatter slit is 0.6°, emission slit is 0.6°, scan range is 0.3–80°, scanning speed is 1°min−1. Raman spectra were recorded on a Jobin–Yvon HR 800 instrument with an Ar+ laser source of 488nm wavelength in a macroscopic configuration. Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) (Leeman Plasma Spec (I)) was used for elemental analyses. Maximum power is 1600W, radio frequency frequency is 3.0MHz. The UV–vis/DRS were obtained on a TU-1901 UV–vis spectrophotometer. Wavelength range testing is 190–900nm, photometric range is −4.0 to 4.0 Abs. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were performed on a VG-ADES 400 instrument with Mg Kα-ADES source at a residual gas pressure of below 10−8 Pa. Binding energies (BE) were referenced to the C1s peak (284.6eV) of the surface adventitious carbon. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on a Hitachi S-4700 microscope. Operating voltage is 5kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on a Hitachi H-7650 microscope with an accelerating voltage of 120kV. The sample was dispersed in ethanol or water, ultrasonic for 5min, then added dropwise to a copper mesh and dried to TEM observation. Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) specific surface areas, pore sizes, and pore volumes were measured on a Quantachrome NovaWin2 model surface analyzer via determination of nitrogen adsorption isotherm at 77K. Total organic carbon (TOC) assays of the degraded solution after 10h of UV irradiation were carried out on a TOC analyzer (Germany TOC-liqui). 2.4 Photocatalytic test The activities of composite were measured under UV light irradiation and microwave-assisted irradiation. The UV source was a 125W mercury (Hg) lamp with maximum emission at approximately 313.2nm. The microwave-assisted photocatalytic degradation used a microwave discharge electrode less lamp (MDEL) as UV source with maximum emission at approximately 280nm. H model 15W MDEL consisted of quartz tubes and was filled with metal Hg and inert gas argon. The output power of the microwave was about 600W [14]. The frequency of microwave was 2450±50MHz. The MDEL was completely immersed in the reaction solution. The equipment was connected with three silicone tubes for letting in and out water and letting out air, respectively, through the hole on the microwave reactor. Air was bubbled into the solution through a sintered glass filter fixed at the bottom of the reactor, not only for providing oxygen but also for mixing the catalyst with the solution. In a typical protocol, the catalyst was dispersed in the solution of organic pollutants (C 0 =50mgL−1) and ultrasonicated for 10min. In the photocatalytic procedure involving UV radiation, catalyst (0.09g) was suspended in freshly prepared aqueous solution of organic pollutant (90mL). In the microwave-assisted photocatalytic procedure, catalyst (0.5g) was suspended in a freshly prepared aqueous solution of RB (500mL). Subsequently, the suspension was stirred in dark for 30min to establish an adsorption–desorption equilibrium between the surface of the catalyst and organic pollutants followed by the exposure of the reaction mixture to the light with continuous stirring. The temperature of the suspension was kept at 30±5°C by circulating solution through a cooler equipped with peristaltic pump. The suspension was centrifuged to remove the catalysts at fixed intervals, and the absorption (A) of the solution of organic pollutant was analyzed by UV–vis scanning spectrophotometer (TU-1901) at λ max. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 FT-IR analysis The infrared absorption spectra of the (a) PS spheres, (b) PW11Co, (c) 3DOM TiO2, and (d) 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 are shown in Fig. 2 . Fig. 2(a) shows the absorption peaks at wave numbers 3024.5 and 2920.4cm−1 corresponding to the aromatic CH stretching vibration and the absorption peaks at the wave numbers 1600.9, 1492.5, and 1451.5cm−1 correspond to aromatic CC stretching vibration; thus, demonstrating the existence of benzene rings. The absorption peaks at the wave numbers of 155.5 and 696.4cm−1 are attributed to CH out-of-plane bending vibration confirming the presence of PS [15,16]. Moreover, Fig. 2(b) exhibits the characteristic peaks corresponding to PW11Co ranging from 700 to 1100cm−1, and the stretching vibrations are as follows: PO (1060cm−1), WO (960cm−1), and WOW (889, 816, and 719cm−1) ascribed to the PW11Co Keggin unit [17]. The absorption peaks at the wave numbers of 3400–3600cm−1 are ascribed to the stretching vibration of OH. Fig. 2(c) displays that the peak observed at 480–800cm−1 in the spectra of 3DOM TiO2 corresponds to the TiO bending mode of TiO2 [18]. However, in Fig. 2(d), absorption bands of PS are not observed indicating that the calcination of the sample precursors led to the complete removal of the PS template from the as-fabricated samples. Moreover, Fig. 2(d) not only displays a peak similar to that observed in Fig. 2(c), but also a weak characteristic peak attributed to POM is obtained in 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 materials, indicating low content of PW11Co, and the absorption band of Ti–O overlaps some characteristic peaks of PW11Co. According to the literature [19], a weak peak appearing at 669cm−1 is assigned to the vibration corresponding to CoN dative bond; however, Fig. 2(d) does not display any peak at 669cm−1. Therefore, Raman spectroscopy was used to confirm the above mentioned description. 3.2 XRD analysis XRD was performed to investigate the crystal phase and crystallite size of TiO2, 3DOM TiO2, PW11Co–APS–TiO2, and 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 as shown in Fig. 3 . The characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to anatase reflection in all the samples are observed at 2θ =25.28, 36.95, 37.80, 38.58, 48.05, 53.89, and 55.06°, respectively (JCPDF card 21-1272). Relatively sharp peaks indicate that the samples are composed of highly crystalline anatase TiO2. Moreover, all the peaks could be assigned to the anatase phase without any indication of crystalline PW11Co demonstrating that PW11Co cluster was neither in the octahedral interstitial sites nor in the substitutional positions of TiO2, and the resulting materials did not exist in the free solid acid [20]. The average crystallite sizes (D*) of different samples (see Table 1 ) are calculated using Scherrer's equation. Compared to TiO2 and PW11Co–APS–TiO2, the D* of 3DOM materials are obviously enlarged. However, in this study, compared to the D* of TiO2 and 3DOM TiO2, PW11Co–APS–TiO2 and 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 displayed a decrease in their size. This was attributed to the fact that coordinate bond between PW11Co and APS–TiO2 inhibited the growth of nanocrystalline TiO2. 3.3 ICP-AES analysis Elemental analysis was performed to investigate the element content of P and W in 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 and 3DOM PW11Co–TiO2 without functionalization of the Ti supports with amine ligand. The samples were analyzed after washing. The result showed that, for all the samples, the molar ratio P:W was determined to be ca. 1:11, suggesting that the starting PW11Co possessed Keggin structure, and decomposition was not observed during the preparation of hybrid catalysts. Moreover, compared to 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2, the loading of PW11Co in the catalyst 3DOM PW11Co–TiO2 was very low; thus, indicating that only the electrostatic rather than chemical interaction existed between PW11Co and TiO2 in the 3DOM PW11Co–TiO2 composite. Furthermore, the removal of PW11Co from the hybrid photocatalyst was hardly observed during photocatalytic test of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2. Therefore, functionalization of the Ti supports with amine ligand was indispensable to prepare stable monosubstituted POM hybrid catalysts. 3.4 UV–vis/DRS Fig. 4 exhibits the UV–vis/DRS of TiO2, PW11Co, PW11Co–APS–TiO2, and 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2. Intense absorption bands of PW11Co are observed at 200 and 260nm, corresponding to charge-transfer from an O 2p to a W 5d in monosubstituted POM cluster at WO and WOW bonds, respectively, which has been described as the characteristic band of Keggin-type [21]. Moreover, all the samples exhibited a wide optical absorption in the range below 380nm, and the absorption edge of 320nm was attributed to the band–band electron transition of the TiO2 nanocrystals according to its band gap energy (E g ) ca. 3.2eV [22]. The absorption edge of 200 and 260nm was attributed to the charge-transfer transition of O→M in PW11Co of hybrid catalysts. Compared to TiO2, the absorption bands of both PW11Co–APS–TiO2 and 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 are broaden, indicating the existence of some interactions between PW11Co and TiO2. However, in 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2, the red-shift of absorption band (ca. 30nm) was observed compared to PW11Co–APS–TiO2, and the increase in the width of this band was attributed to the interactions between 3DOM TiO2 and PW11Co, and to the changes in coordination environment of Ti species due to PW11Co anchored to the amine-modified 3DOM TiO2 surface [23,24], thus leading to an enhancement in the photocatalytic activity. Furthermore, the energy band gaps of all the samples were calculated according to the optical absorption edge obtained from UV–vis/DRS spectra by using the following formula: (αhν) n = K(hν−E g ), where a is the absorption coefficient, K is the parameter related to the effective masses associated with the valence and conduction bands, n is 1/2 for a direct transition, hν is the absorption energy, and E g is the band gap energy. Fig. 4(b) shows the polt of (αhν) n versus hν based on the spectral response, and the extrapolated intercept corresponds to E g value. Calculated E g of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 and PW11Co–APS–TiO2 are 2.39 and 2.48eV, respectively. Compared to TiO2, the E g s of both PW11Co–APS–TiO2 and 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 decreased leading to an improvement in the photocatalytic activities. 3.5 Raman spectra The phase structures of PW11Co, 3DOM TiO2, and 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 were identified with sensitivity by Raman spectroscopy as shown in Fig. 5 . The anatase phase shows major Raman bands at 143, 395, 515, and 639cm−1. These bands are attributed to the four Raman-active modes of anatase phase associated with the symmetries of E g , B 1g , A 1g , and E 2g , respectively. Raman spectrum of PW11Co exhibits the characteristic peak at 989.34cm−1 corresponding to the stretching vibration of WOd bond, and the weak peaks at 890–850cm−1 are attributed to stretching vibration of WOb bond, consistent with the Keggin structure of PW11Co. The above mentioned four peaks are also observed for 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 corresponding to the anatase TiO2. However, the intensity of the peak at 143cm−1 increased, simultaneously, the intensity of the peak corresponding to 395, 515, and 639cm−1 became much weaker. The above mentioned changes in Raman spectra and peak intensities are due to the strong interactions between the Keggin unit PW11Co and the anatase 3DOM TiO2 network. Simultaneously, the characteristic peaks of PW11Co appear at 989.34cm−1, indicating that the Keggin structure of PW11Co is retained. However, the peak had low intensity due to the amount of the doped heteropolyacid. Moreover, a weak and new peak is observed at 669cm−1 in the hybrid catalysts. This weak but distinct peak was assigned to the vibration of CoN dative bond [19], which was formed via coordination of Co centers with the nitrogen atom of amine groups on the surface of APS–Ti support. 3.6 XPS analysis Fig. 6 displays the XPS demonstrating the characterization of the surface composition of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2. Fig. 6(a) shows that 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 is mainly composed of Ti, O, P, W, Co, N, C, and Si. The binding energies (BE) of Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 are 458.3 and 464.1eV, respectively, as shown in Fig. 6(b), which are ascribed to the Ti4+ oxidation state [25]. However, the BE were observed about shifting 0.1eV, indicating that chemical environment was changed due to the incorporation of PW11Co into 3DOM TiO2 via coupling agent APS. In Fig. 6(c), the peak observed at 529.7eV is attributed to the surface lattice oxygen [26]. The presence of adsorbed OH was signified by a new XPS peak at 531.8eV in the O1s region [27]. These free amines correspond to the peak component at 398.7eV in the N1s spectrum (Fig. 6(d)). However, some amino groups may also undergo H-bonding with each other or with substrate hydroxyls, as revealed by the presence of a shoulder at 400.7eV [28]. The BE from 133.5 to 134.0eV is assigned to P5+. In this study, the BE of the P2P component is found to be 134.0eV as exhibited in Fig. 6(e), which is a typical value for P5+ [29,30]. The BEs of W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2 are 36.5 and 38.5eV, respectively, as shown in Fig. 6(f), and the chemical state of W corresponds to PW11Co [31]. The spectrum of Co reveals a 2P3/2 peak at 781.6eV in Fig. 6(g), ascribed to oxidic Co (Co2+) [32]. These results are consistent with the structural analysis of PW11Co and TiO2. 3.7 SEM and TEM image SEM was used to characterize the morphologies of the PS colloidal crystal template and of different composites. Fig. 7(a–c) shows monodispersed PS spheres exhibiting an average diameter of 200nm, arranged in a typically ordered hexagonal pattern corresponding to the (111) plane of face centered cubic close packing. The SEM of 3DOM TiO2 and 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 under different magnifications show uniform macroporous structure with uniform thickness of the walls of the macropores as shown in Fig. 7(d–f) and Fig. 7(g–i). Fig. 7(d–f) exhibit three apparent small holes inside every macropore, derived from necks between the original PS spheres, thus confirming that all the macropores are well-connected. 3DOM Ti structures were obtained in high yield. Large fractions of the samples had size range in several micrometers. The 3DOM TiO2 clearly retained the 3D order of the colloidal crystal template covering a large area and exhibited an ordered pattern of pores. Though precursor (TTIP) is remarkably vicious, the incomplete filling can be avoided effectively due to forced impregnation. However, Fig. 7(g–i) demonstrate that, compared to 3DOM TiO2 the pore wall of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 is thicker and less smooth because of the incorporation of APS and PW11Co. Moreover, it still exhibits a highly ordered and interconnected honeycomb pore structure on the whole, and only a small part of the pore is observed to be blocked. Fig. 7(j–l) shows that PW11Co–APS–TiO2 is composed of irregular nanoparticles, loosely arranged with serious reunion. Compared to PW11Co–APS–TiO2, the structure of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 is multi-layered with open pores, thus significantly improving the accessibility of diffusing species (i.e. organic pollutants) to the composite, resulting in larger adsorption of organic pollutants and enhanced photocatalytic activity. Further, more information about the morphology was obtained by TEM as shown in Fig. 8 . The dark regions in each image correspond to the ceramic framework and the light regions represent the void space. These images illustrate the intact spatial periodicity of multiple layers of close packed macropores. The TEM image of 3DOM TiO2 shows smooth macropore wall surfaces before loading PW11Co (Fig. 8a–c). The interconnected worm-like pore structure provides good access to pores for subsequent attaching with APS and PW11Co. Introduction of PW11Co into the mesoporous structure leads to a slight increase in the wall thicknesses, and a rougher surface is observed (Fig. 8d–f), due to the connection of PW11Co on the surface by APS. The results are consistent with the aforementioned SEM analyses. 3.8 Nitrogen adsorption–desorption Fig. 9 shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 and PW11Co–APS–TiO2. Both isotherms are classic type IV (IUPAC classification). The hysteresis loop of PW11Co–APS–TiO2 belongs to type H2, attributed to a difference in mechanism between condensation and evaporation processes occurring in pores with narrow necks and wide bodies (often referred to as ink bottle pores) [33]. However, the isotherm corresponding to 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 has a broad hysteresis loop belonging to type H3, which does not exhibit any limiting adsorption at high P/P 0; and observed with aggregates of plate-like particles giving rise to slit-shaped pores [33]. Moreoever, the isotherm at relative pressure (P/P 0) between 0.4 and 1.0 indicates the presence of mesopores and macropores [34]. The surface of 3DOM TiO2 (91.95m2 g−1) was increased because of the unique pore structure compared to P25 (50m2 g−1) (see Table 1). However, the specific surface area of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 reduced due to the attachment of many PW11Co clusters to APS ligands grafted to 3DOM TiO2, simultaneously, leading to the filling of voids of 3DOM TiO2. 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 exhibits smaller value of the total pore volume, as listed in Table 1, further illustrating the success of PW11Co supported on TiO2, resulting in the reduction of voids and the results are consistent with SEM and TEM. The pore-size distribution curves of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 and PW11Co–APS–TiO2 are shown in the inset of Fig. 9. The estimated pore sizes of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 and PW11Co–APS–TiO2 obtained by Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method are 3.5 and 8.1nm, respectively. The sharper and narrower BJH peaks indicate that the pore size of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 is more uniform. The presence of mesoporous structure in the walls is attributed to the accumulation of particles. 3.9 Photocatalytic activity Fig. 10 illustrates the photocatalytic activity of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 toward degradation of organic pollutant. Fig. 10(a) shows that 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 exhibits excellent photocatalytic activity under UV light irradiation compared to direct photolysis, monomers (3DOM TiO2 and PW11Co), and PW11Co–APS–TiO2. However, the photacatalytic activity of PW11Co–APS–TiO2 is lower than that of 3DOM TiO2 and PW11Co, attributed to the following two aspects: first, 3DOM TiO2 possesses open macroporous structure providing more channels to transport organic molecules. Second, PW11Co belongs to water-soluble substance; thus, it undergoes homogeneous photocatalysis. Similarly, Fig. 10(b) displays that 3DOM PW11Ni–APS–TiO2 exhibits the best degradation activity under UV light irradiation. Fig. 10(c) shows the photodegradation of RB using different transition metal-substituted POMs (MCo, Ni, Mn) loaded amine functionalized 3DOM TiO2 and 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 shows superior performance. The temporal evolution of the changes in absorption spectra accompanying the photodegradation of RB over 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 is shown in Fig. 10(d). RB dye initially showed a major absorption band at 554nm, and its color nearly disappeared with the increase in irradiation time. Moreover, 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 exhibits an efficient and superior photocatalytic activity under UV light irradiation, for different types of organic pollutants (Fig. 10e). The results of photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants reveal that 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 exhibit high photocatalytic activity under UV light and microwave-assisted irradiation (Fig. 10e and f). TOC experiment was performed to investigate the degree of mineralization of RB, and the result was shown in Fig. S1 of the supporting information. Compared with 3DOM TiO2 and without catalyst, the degree of mineralization of RB is the highest using 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 as catalyst after UV irradiation 10h. Although the mineralization rate of RB with 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 was only 38.3% for 10h, which can be speculated that the mineralization was better with time delaied. Furthermore, to investigate the activity of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2, the cyclic experiments were performed as shown in Fig. S2 of the supporting information. After three runs for the photocatalytic degradation of RB, the activities of as-composite exhibited insignificant changes revealing that 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 has excellent catalytic activity. In addition, this further proves that PW11Co is scarcely any lost. A series of photocatalytic tests demonstrated that 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 displayed significant catalytic activity and acted as a potential candidate for degradation of organic pollutants. Therefore, 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 is an efficient catalyst and the careful analyses reveal following advantages: first, 3DOM materials possessing spatial periodicity in their dielectric constant improve the mass transport in catalysis process. 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 possesses uniform channels, significantly improving the accessibility of diffusing species (i.e., organic pollutant) to the frame, resulting in a larger adsorption of organic pollutant, thus leading to an enhancement in the photocatalytic performance; second, during the photocatalysis of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2, photo-electrons of 3DOM TiO2 in the excited state are extracted and transferred to PW11Co, and consequently the rapid recombination of the charge pair was retarded because of PW11Co acting as an efficient electrons trapper to form a comparatively stable reduction product of PW11Co; and third, UV radiation generated by the MDEL in the microwave field directly destroys organic pollutant by bond cleavage. Moreover, UV irradiation only effects of the highly defected catalysts increases the probability of transition of photon-generated electrons and decreases the e−–h+ recombination. 3.10 Photocatalytic kinetics In this study, RB was selected as a reference to investigate the kinetics of degradation of dye in aqueous solution under UV–light irradiation, and the results are shown in Fig. 11(a) indicating that it follows an apparent first-order reaction which is in agreement with a generally observed Langmuir–Hinshelwood kinetics model: (1) − ln C 0 C t = k t where k is the apparent first-order rate constant, and the value of k gives an indication of the activity of the photocatalyst. However, the results reveal that the degradation of 3DOM TiO2 and 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 is not consistent with pseudo first-order reaction as shown in Fig. 11(a). Therefore, different models were selected to explain the degradation of RB using 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 as phoocatalyst. Analysis of Fig. 11(b) shows that their degradation is ascribed to a zero-order reaction: (2) C t = − k t The corresponding reaction rates of different samples are calculated (see Table 2 ) and they showed following trend: 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 >PW11Co>3DOM TiO2 >PW11Co–APS–TiO2 >direct photolysis. 3.11 Dominant active species capture experimental According to the literature, during photocatalytic degradation, tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) and p-benzoquinone (BQ) are used as capture agents for OH• and O2−•. To investigate the dominant active species in the process of photocatalysis, the above mentioned capture agents were employed in photocatalytic degradation of RB under UV light using 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 as photocatalyst. During the photocatalytic degradation of RB under UV light using 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2, capture agent (10mM) was added into the reaction suspension after absorption and desorption equilibrium was attained and the results are shown in Fig. 12 . The rates of degradation of RB decrease after adding capture agents. Moreover, after adding TBA, the rate of degradation of RB decreased by 60%. The above mentioned results indicated that the dominant active species in the process of photocatalysis are OH• and O2−•. Moreover, concentration of OH• is more than that of O2−•. Based on these results, the possible photocatalytic mechanism of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 was speculated. 3.12 Proposed possible photocatalytic procedure and mechanism As shown in Fig. 13 , when the catalyst is added to the dye solution, the pollutant molecules enter into the macroporous channel. The multi-layer structure and open pores on the surface of the catalyst facilitate the adsorption of the reactants on a larger area leading to their entrance into the pores of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 with increased reactive sites. Correspondingly, the products are transported more easily through the openings through the macroporous channels. Consequently, the results indicated convenient and improved photocatalytic reaction with significantly enhanced photocatalytic activity of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2. Based on dominant active species capture experiments, the possible photocatalytic mechanism of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 was proposed. Scheme 2 illustrates that under UV light irradiation, hybrid catalysts possess two active components (TiO2 and PW11Co). Fig. 14 demonstrates that irradiation of TiO2 under the UV light excites the electrons leading to the formation of photoinduced electrons and photogenerated holes. The photogenerated holes react with H2O to generate OH• radicals. The O2 acts as an efficient electron trapper to generate O2−•. The reactive oxygen species (e.g.: OH• and O2−•) promote the degradation and mineralization of organic pollutant. Moreover, O2p →W5d empty orbital transitions occur when PW11Co is exposed to UV irradiation, and the charge transfer takes place from O2− to W6+ of WOW, resulting in the formation of a pair of a hole (O−) and a trapped electron center (W5+). The [W5+ O− W6+]* is also the reactive species exhibiting strong oxidation ability for the degradation of organic pollutant. The organic pollutant was finally degraded into H2O and CO2. Moreover, synergistic effect was observed between PW11Co and 3DOM TiO2, and e− produced by 3DOM TiO2 were captured by [W5+ O− W6+]* to achieve effective separation of the charges, thus improving the photocatalytic activity. When TiO2 was irradiated by UV light, photogenerated electrons are excited and captured by PW11Co, leading to a decrease in concentration of O2−• produced by the interaction between photogenerated electrons and O2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface. This is consistent with the results obtained from dominant active species capture experiment. Furthermore, the results proved the existence of synergistic effects between 3DOM TiO2 and PW11Co. 4 Conclusions The novel hybrid photocatalyst was fabricated by self-assembly method using APS-functionalized 3DOM Ti as the support, and PW11Co as the active sites. The characterized results showed that the primary Keggin structure of PW11Co was anchored on the surface of amine-functionalized 3DOM Ti support via CoN dative bonding. The 3DOM structure was retained in the product. The photocatalytic activities of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 are excellent for the degradation of different types of organic pollutants because of the synergistic effect between 3DOM TiO2 and PW11Co, and the open macroporous structure is conducive to the transportation of reactants. Furthermore, in our study, possible photocatalytic procedure and mechanism were proposed. Therefore, not just ordinary electrostatic interaction but coordinate bond between PW11Co and 3DOM TiO2 enhanced the photocatalytic activity and the ability to be readily separated from the reaction system is enhanced. The novel hybrid catalysts act as potential candidate for the treatment of organic pollutants in aqueous systems. coredata.dc:description: A novel and efficient, amine-functionalized three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) titanium (Ti) catalyst modified using transition metal-monosubstituted polyoxometalate (3DOM K5[Co(H2O)PW11O39]–(EtO)3SiCH2CH2CH2NH2–TiO2 or 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2) was fabricated by self-assembly method. First, methanol bath was used to soak polystyrene spheres to obtain large size 3DOM TiO2, which was further functionalized using 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APS). Amine-functionalized 3DOM TiO2 materials impregnated with monosubstituted polyoxometalate (POM, K5[Co(H2O)PW11O39]) were prepared by coordination of cobalt (Co) present in the units of POM, with the amine groups present on the surface of 3DOM TiO2. The materials so obtained were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry, Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Scanning electron microscopy, Transmission electron microscopy, and nitrogen adsorption–desorption tests. The results showed that the primary Keggin structures of the composites remained intact, simultaneously, 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 had anatase crystalline structure, and PW11Co was successfully bonded to 3DOM TiO2 by CoN bond with APS as the coupling agent. Broadening of absorption band was observed for the product compared to the monomers, 3DOM TiO2 and PW11Co. However, the 3DOM structure was retained in the product; therefore, the accessibility of the diffusing species was significantly improved because of the permeability offered by the macroporous structure. The UV photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants revealed better activities of 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 compared to PW11Co, 3DOM TiO2, and PW11Co–APS–TiO2. Moreover, 3DOM PW11Co–APS–TiO2 exhibited superior photocatalytic degradation of Rhodamine B (RB), Salicylic acid (SA), Congo red (CR), and Malachite green oxalate (MG) under microwave-assisted irradiation. Leakage of PW11Co from the hybrid photocatalyst was barely observed during the photocatalytic tests, attributed to strong coordination interactions between the Keggin units and the amine-functionalized Ti surface. The capture experimental results of photocatalysis revealed that the dominant active species were OH• and O2−•. Moreover, in this study, the procedure and possible mechanism of the UV photodegradation of organic pollutants in the aqueous system was proposed and discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation, characterization, and photocatalytic activity of three-dimensionally ordered macroporous hybrid monosubstituted polyoxometalate K5[Co(H2O)PW11O39] amine functionalized titanium catalysts
